oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joan Crawford in "Sadie McKee"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1980
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sadie McKee (Joan Crawford) is a cook's daughter and works a maid for the wealthy Alderson family. Although she flirts with her employer, Mike Alderson (Franchot Tone), she loves her humble boyfriend Tommy Wallace (Gene Raymond). The couple runs away to New York to get married, but before the ceremony Wallace meets a showgirl and deserts McKee. She decides to stay in the city, and gets a job in a nightclub owned by alcoholic millionaire Jack Brennan (Edward Arnold). Brennan is smitten with McKee, who eventually gives up on finding true love and marries Brennan for his money. She is unhappy, however, and leaves him when she finds out that Wallace is in trouble. With Alderson's help, she eventually discovers that he is extremely ill in a hospital. She goes to visit him, and he pair confess their love for each other shortly before Wallace dies.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Cora de Garmo
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Murillo Studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nutritionists -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo made in St. Louis, Missouri, in 1913. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). She married Charles W. Bryan Jr., a prominent civil engineer, on June 9, 1920. During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View on World's Fair Grounds (Looking toward the Sunsphere)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henley Street Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Thompson's Inc.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Henley Street Bridge was built at a cost of $1 million between 1930 and 1932. After the Fort Loudon Dam was completed and its reservoir filled in 1943, the water level in the Tennessee River rose by several feet and so changed the appearance of the bridge. This image shows several of the shoals characteristic of the lower water level.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Sevier's "Marble Springs Plantation"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sevier, John, 1745-1815
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Sevier was born in 1745 in Virginia. He fought in the Revolutionary War (most notably at the Battle of Kings Mountain) and was later involved in the short-lived State of Franklin and the campaign for Tennessee statehood. When Sevier became Tennessee's first governor in 1796, he settled in South Knox County. Here, he constructed "Marble Springs Plantation," which consisted of a main building (shown) and several smaller outbuildings. Sevier died in Alabama in 1815 and was removed to the Knox County Courthouse lawn in 1889. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Robertson, Ernest Bryan, 1928-
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gillette Ranch Hallway
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dapprich, Frederic R, 1880-1965
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Los Angeles County (Calif.) -- Pictorial works
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Bryan and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion pictures, American
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Bryan and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John T. Whitaker and Hubert R. Knickerbocker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Whitaker, John T. (John Thompson), 1906-
Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. The man seen with him in this picture is likely fellow reporter Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This building is the second of the two Southern Methodist Episcopal Churches that stood on Church Street between 1836 and 1928. It was built in 1875 and burned down in 1928. After the fire, the congregation elected to build a new structure on the corner of Henley and Main Streets, which continues to operate today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence and Alice (Joyce) Brown
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Joyce, Alice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alice Joyce was born on October 1, 1890 in Kansas City, Missouri. She worked as a telephone operator and as a fashion model before entering film in 1910. She went on earn the nickname "The Madonna of the Screen" and to make a number of silent films, including "Whom the Gods Destroy" (1916), "Within the Law" (1917), "Stella Dallas" (1925), and "So's Your Old Man" (1926). Joyce retired in 1930 with the advent of "talkies." She was married three times: first to Tom Moore (from 1914 to 1920), second to James Regan (from 1920 to 1932), and finally to Clarence Brown (from 1933 to 1945). Alice Joyce Brown died of heart disease on October 9, 1955 and was buried in the San Fernando Mission Cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knox County Court House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Standard News Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Two of the monuments on the courthouse's grounds are visible in this image%3A the obelisk commemorates Tennessee's first governor John Sevier, while the marble archway honors Confederate surgeon John Mason Boyd.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "The Signal Tower"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Signal Tower" was one of the earliest movies that Clarence Brown directed. It tells the story of a railroad signal man named David Tolliver (Rockcliffe Fellowes), his wife Sally (Virginia Vallie), and their child Sonny (Frankie Darrow). The family lives near the signal tower where Tolliver works. When the relief signal man retires, his replacement Joe Standish (Wallace Beery) boards with the Tollivers. Standish is evicted after attempting to seduce Sally and arrives at work drunk and late the following night. As a result, Tolliver works an extra shift and Standish attempts to force himself on Sally while he is distracted. Sonny runs to his father for help, but Tolliver is busy preventing a freight train that has broken in half from colliding with the oncoming Limited. Sally takes matters into her own hands, and aims what she believes to be an unloaded gun at Standish. It discharges, however, hitting Standish and so dissuading him. Thus, both the train and Sally's honor are preserved.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burwell Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville Banking and Trust Building was completed in 1907 on the site of the original Blount College. It was Knoxville's tallest building until 1912, when it was surpassed by the Holston. C.B. Atkin later purchased the structure, which he enlarged and renamed the Burwell Building in honor of his wife, Mary Burwell. The structure became famous in 1928, when the Tennessee Theater was added as part of an addition standing at 604-606 Gay Street. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "A Woman of Affairs"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown "Directing Intruder in the Dust"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion pictures, American
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown directing "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Southern Railway Station
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chas. C. Cullen & Co.
Railroads -- Tennessee
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Font of Strong Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flags Outside the Chinese Pavilion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Port of Knoxville Public Terminal
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Robertson, Ernest Bryan, 1928-
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, the TVA made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown at Pump Station
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Louisville & Nashville Railroad Yards and Terminals
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hyde, Victor Albert, 1913-
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1939, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996
Railroads -- Tennessee
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of the Louisville & Nashville Railroad yards and terminals. The Commonwealth of Kentucky granted the L&N a charter on March 5, 1850 and the Tennessee State Legislature authorized the railroad's extension to Nashville on December 4, 1851. The railroad began expanding after the Civil War and eventually reached such cities as Knoxville (Tennessee), Montgomery (Alabama), Norton (Virginia), and New Orleans (Louisiana). By the time the Seabord Coastline Railroad bought the L&N in 1971, it operated 6,574 miles of track in 13 states.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. James Hotel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: E.C. Kropff Co.
Hotels -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center%3A WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rudolph Valentino, Clarence Brown, and Arabella Brown on the Set of "The Eagle"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Appalachian Exposition Main Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.H. Kress & Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal: to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Motor Section Training
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawley, Thomas J, 1914-1999
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original caption for this image reads "Motor squad and gun. Camp Barkley, Texas April-1941. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of construction at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "Inspiration"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In "Inspiration," Andre Martel (Robert Montgomery), a diplomat studying for the consular service, falls in love with Yvonne Valbret (Greta Garbo), an artist's model. The two become lovers, but Martel leaves when he learns of Valbret's sordid past. He later finds her poverty-stricken and buys her a country home out of pity. He also tells Valbret that he is going to marry another woman, and she pleads with him to marry her instead. Remembering his friend Liane Latour (Karen Morley), who killed herself when her lover Raymond Delval (Lewis Stone) left her, Martel goes to Valbret to rekindle their relationship. When he arrives, he finds another of Valbret's lovers begging her to return to him. Martel agrees to overlook this indiscretion, but Valbret, determined not to destroy him, writes him a farewell note and leaves while he is asleep.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Irene Dunne and Alan Marshal in "The White Cliffs of Dover"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The White Cliffs of Dover" begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

Regas, Frank, 1888-1953
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Greek immigrants George and Frank Regas started the Regas Brothers Cafe (originally known as the Astor Cafe) on Gay Street in 1919. The restaurant stayed open 24 hours a day, except for Christmas Eve and part of Christmas Day. The Regas family continues to operate the eatery, now called Regas Restaurant, today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flag Outside the United States Pavilion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dining Room in the Blount Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: William Blount Mansion Association
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Blount, William, 1749-1800
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henson Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When Mrs. Martha C. Henson died in 1927, she left the University of Tennessee $200,000 to be used for the betterment of the school's female students. The money was used to build a women's dormitory, which opened in 1930 and was named Henson Hall in her honor. The building housed Air Cadet Training Program students from 1943 until June of 1944, but returned to housing women as soon as the program ended. It became an academic building in the late 1970s, and continues to serve in this capacity today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T. B. Bayless
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Rawls family
Hoskins family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Students in Front of Strong Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dudney, Wallace N. (Wallace Neal), 1923-2006
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of John T. Whitaker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fayer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crowds on the International Court of Flags
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Cherokee Country Club's original clubhouse (shown here) was constructed in 1907. This structure was demolished in 1928 to make way for a more elaborate clubhouse designed by Knoxville architects Baumann and Baumann. The Tennessee River's Horseshoe Bend (today a National Military Park commemorating the Battle of Horseshoe Bend fought there on March 27, 1814) is shown as it appears from the clubhouse.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville Street Market
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville street market, likely on Market Street near the Market House. Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: One of the Better Streets of the Dale Avenue District
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1919, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some of the nicer homes located in the Dale Avenue District. Welles places this area in the Northwest District, which she describes as "essentially a mill section, [as] many of its inhabitants depend ... for their living on the large mills." She finds the homes to be "poorly constructed in most instances" but does not find the living conditions as deplorable as they are in some of the other sections.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This house, which stood on Rose Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee, was home to Professor Charles C. Ross beginning in 1891. His sister Nellie lived with him from 1895 until she married James Milton Bailey in 1898. Another (currently unidentified) individual may also have occupied the house during this time. Charles Ross, Nellie Ross, and an illegible name are inscribed on the back of the picture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John T. Whitaker and Hubert R. Knickerbocker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knickerbocker, H. R. (Hubert Renfro), 1898-1949
Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Park City High School was built in 1907. For a brief time, it was the largest high school in Knoxville. It later became Park Lowry Grammar School and was closed in 1982. The building was sold to private contractors in the mid 1980s, but was completely razed after being badly damaged by fire in September of 1987.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View toward the Candy Factory from near the Information Kiosk
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1991, East Tennessee Historical Society, 500 W. Church Avenue, Knoxville, TN 37902
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Robertson, Ernest Bryan, 1928-
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brabson's Ferry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: F.G. Asquith Co.
Sevier County (Tenn.) -- History
French Broad River (N.C. And Tenn.) -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brabson Island, site of Brabson's Ferry Plantation, sits in the French Broad River in Sevier County, Tennessee. Since this postcard was mailed in 1913, the notation "Brabson's Ferry near Knoxville, Tenn." most likely refers to the ferry that crosses the French Broad several miles upstream of Brabson Island rather than to the Plantation or to the island proper. Brabson's Ferry Plantation was added to the National Register of Historic Places on June 25, 1975.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dapprich, Frederic R, 1880-1965
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Los Angeles County (Calif.) -- Pictorial works
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Farragut
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Strong Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lawson McGhee Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Standard News Agency
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Libraries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Auditorium of the First Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: E. C. Kropp Co.
Hotels -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Andrew Johnson Hotel opened on Gay Street in 1929 and prospered throughout the Great Depression. Its numerous guests included Jean Paul Sarte, Duke Ellington, Amelia Erhart, Liberace, Tony Perkins, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Knox County purchased the building in 1990, and is considering selling the property for a mix of residential and commercial uses as of June 2007. This particular postcard was mailed on October 13, 1934 from Chattanooga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.H. Kress & Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In early 1892, W.W. Woodruff offered his lot on Deaderick Street and his help raising funds to Knoxville's First Baptist Church in order to organize a new church. The product of these efforts was Centennial Baptist Church (renamed Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church in 1905), which was dedicated on September 13, 1892. The church was destroyed by fire in 1909, but was quickly rebuilt and continued to prosper for many years. Unfortunately, it no longer exists today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Students in Strong Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Library Initiatives
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Whittle Springs Hotel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: E.C. Kropp Co.
Hotels -- Tennessee
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pond on Gillette Ranch
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Circle Park Neighborhood
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.H. Kress & Co.
University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Circle Park neighborhood was home to many of Knoxville's richest and most prominent citizens during the early part of the 20th century. The area began to decline in the 1940s, and the University of Tennessee bought most of the neighborhood in the 1950s. Between 1960 and 1968, the University razed the original structures to make way for such buildings as the Andy Holt Tower and the McClung Museum, many of which are still in use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Goetz Sanitarium
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Hospitals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Edward Goetz, founder of the Goetz Sanitarium, was born to Edward and Sarah Jane (Hawn) Goetz on February 16, 1874 in Louisville, Tennessee. He attended the Bell House School and the University of Tennessee before graduating from the Tennessee Medical College in 1905. He married Beatrice Hollister on January 24, 1898, and the couple had at least three children%3A Royal Frank, Beatrice, and Helena. Goetz did postgraduate work in 1906 and eventually specialized in otolaryngology. He later became interested in narcotics addicts and attended a special course in mental and nervous diseases in New York in 1913. He founded the Goetz Sanitarium on North Broadway upon his return to Knoxville. He moved his hospital to the Fountain Head Hotel in 1917, and continued to work here until his death following the removal of a brain tumor on December 2, 1927.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Holston National Bank Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville Banking and Trust constructed this building, best known as the Holston National Bank Building, in 1912. At 12 stories, it was Knoxville's tallest edifice until 1928, when it was surpassed by the Andrew Johnson Building. The Holston National Bank became the Holston-Union Bank in 1928 and the Hamilton National Bank (now known as the First Tennessee Bank) in 1931. Although the Holston no longer serves the financial industry, it has been repurposed as a luxury residence building and continues to be a prominent Knoxville landmark.

The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Morgan Hall (UT Agricultural Campus)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Knoxville Engraving Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Morgan Hall was constructed on the University of Tennessee's Agricultural Campus in 1921. Originally called the Agricultural Hall, it was later renamed in honor of Harcourt A. Morgan, who arranged for the State of Tennessee to provide the money needed for its construction. Although space needs have changed many times since the building's construction, care has been taken to maintain the its architectural and historical integrity and it is still in use today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chinese Pavilion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Graf-Cullum House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Richard F. Graf designed and built this house at 325 Woodlawn Pike in about 1923. The Graf family lived in this home for many years before Dr. J.P. Cullum acquired it. Graf and several of his sons operated the architecture firm R.F. Graf & Sons in downtown Knoxville from 1910 until 1942.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Craighead-Jackson House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Toms Family
Knoxville, Tenn. -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Craighead constructed the Craighead-Jackson House in 1818. After Robert Craighead II sold the property in 1855, the structure passed through many hands and fell into serious disrepair. In the late 1950s, the Blount Mansion Association arranged for the home's restoration. The edifice opened as a museum on 3 April 1966 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. This museum also houses William Perry "Buck" Toms' collection of 18th century silver, said to be the finest in the Southeast.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Yoholo Micco, A Creek Chief
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: King, Charles Bird, 1785-1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Frederick W. Greenough
Published 1868
Rice, Rutter, and Company, Philadelpha, Pennsylvania
Creek Indians -- Kings and rulers.
Creek Indians -- Tribal government.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Yoholo Micco was the principal chief of the Eufalo town on the Tallapoosa River. He was one of the Creek delagates who travelled to Washington, DC in 1826 in order to argue against the Treaty of Indian Springs, which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government. His later support of the US Government cost him his office, and he later removed to Arkansas, where he died. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 3rd Platoon, Company A of the 109th Engineers Combat Battalion After African Campaign
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945 -- Participation, American
Soldiers -- South Dakota
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 109th Engineer Regiment was organized as a South Dakota National Guard unit in 1924. It was called up for federal service on February 10, 1941 and trained in Louisiana before being sent to Camp Killadeas, Ireland in preparation for the invasion of North Africa. The 109th was among the first units to land in Algiers in November of 1942 and eventually fought in the Italian theater as well. The unit was deactivated after V-E Day but called up again in 1950 for further service in Germany. Most of the unit had returned home by 1952, where it resumed its duties with the National Guard. The 109th also served in Iraq before the unit was formally deactivated in Sturgis, South Dakota on August 18, 2007.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Appalachian Exposition Administration Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chapman Drug Co.
Expositions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of single-family home located at 1205 W. Clinch Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee. According to Victor A. Hyde, this residence is located in a B-type district, which he defines as one "occupied by white occupants, in which the residences range in value from $2,500 to $10,000." These communities generally separate wealthy A-type communities from poorer C-type communities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville's Masonic Temple was originally Charles McClung McGhee's private home. The structure was designed by architect Joseph F. Baumann in 1872 and altered to serve as the Masonic Temple after McGhee's death in 1907. The interior of the home was restored in the early 1990s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Souvenir Post Card Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Brownlow, William Gannaway, 1805-1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peruvian Pavilion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chilhowee Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Chilhowee Lake (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park's lake. Among the visible structures are the Southern States Building and the lake's distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Island Home Farm
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Asheville Post Card Co.
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
Dickinson Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located in the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Viaduct
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville Sentinel Building during the World Series
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
World Series (Baseball)
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the 1920s, the Knoxville Sentinel maintained a board that allowed fans to keep up with the World Series game. It was manned by two boys%3A one (seen near the policeman's perch) relayed news to the crowd via megaphone, and the other (seen at the bottom of the board) updated the posted score. In this 1921 event, the Giants beat the Yankees 5-3.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John T. Whitaker with Group
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Phillips, John, 1914-1996
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - PUBLIC SCHOOLS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee State Capitol Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Detroit Photographic Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Politics And Government
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Park Inn
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1991, East Tennessee Historical Society, 500 West Church Avenue, Knoxville, TN 37902
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Description And Travel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Park Inn opened in late 1931 in what had been Phi Gamma Delta's Fraternity House at 1541 West Cumberland Avenue. Although it advertised itself as "Knoxville's Outstanding Tourist Home ... Strictly High Class," the enterprise failed in about 1933. Although a private citizen rented out its furnished rooms in 1934, it was once again home to a fraternity (this time Alpha Tau Omega) by 1935.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Second Presbyterian Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ramage & Co.
Presbyterians -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville Traction Company Reservoir and Power House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Reese & Read Publishers
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Industries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville Traction Company was chartered on March 31, 1898 and eventually operated some 60 electric streetcars on 30 miles of track. It became part of the Knoxville Railway and Light Company when all transit and electric operations were consolidated in 1908. The eventual successor of this organization, the Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB), continues to serve the city today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Medical Arts Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Standard News Agency
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Medical Arts Building, located on Knoxville's Main Street, was completed in 1930. It was constructed under the direct supervision of the medical profession so that it could be tailored to meet the individual needs of each tenant. For many years, it was considered one of the finest Medical Arts Buildings in the United States. The structure has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1984.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: World's Fair Grounds
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1919, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typical houses on Knoxville's Dale Avenue. Welles places this area in the Northwest District, which she describes as "essentially a mill section, [as] many of its inhabitants depend ... for their living on the large mills." She finds the homes to be "poorly constructed in most instances" but does not find the living conditions as deplorable as they are in some of the other sections.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wedding Breakfast in "The White Cliffs of Dover"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture producers and directors
Dunne, Irene, 1898-1990
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown giving Irene Dunne last-minute direction on the set of "The White Cliffs of Dover." The movie begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chairlifts on the World's Fair Grounds
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture producers and directors
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown playing a reporter in "The Acquittal." The movie tells the story of Andrew Prentice (Charles Wellesley) who has two unrelated adopted sons: Kenneth Winthrop (Richard Travers) and Robert Armstrong (Norman Kerry). Winthrop is married to Madeline Ames (Claire Windsor). When Prentice is found dead, Winthrop is charged with and acquitted of the crime. Thus, it falls to Madeline to find the real killer.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing Greta Garbo in "Romance"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View on the Set of "The White Cliffs of Dover"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The White Cliffs of Dover" begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "A Woman of Affairs"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and latin. The institute was merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rudolph Valentino in "The Eagle"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Methodist Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Souvenir Post Card Co.
Methodists -- Tennessee
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.
