oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Training at Camp Barkley
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawley, Thomas J, 1914-1999
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original caption for this image reads "Camp Barkley. Dec 9 1941. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joan Crawford in "Possessed"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Sunsphere
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville Court House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Detroit photographic company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History.
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

According to Victor Hyde, such mills were of of considerable local economic importance even though they produced much less than the plants in Western Tennessee and little of their product was shipped outside of East Tennessee.

McClung, and James Cowan operated an extremely successful dry goods wholesale business called Cowan, McClung, and Co. in central Knoxville during the early part of the 20th century. Built in 1875, this home was designed by Nashville architect P.J. Williamson and stood on Main Avenue until it was destroyed in about 1964.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown and Greta Garbo on the Set of "Flesh and the Devil"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aftermath of the "Million Dollar Fire"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of Gay Street after Knoxville's "Million Dollar Fire." This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scene from "The Eagle"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

African Americans -- Knoxville (Tenn.)
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Richard "Uncle Dick" Payne (1813-1885) sold water to Knoxvillians from his two-wheeled cart from 1845 until his death in 1885. He was an extremely popular merchant and is generally recognized as Knoxville's first "water works." Payne Street (in the Reservoir Hill area) is named in his honor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ellis and Earnest Drugstore
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History.
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: College friends Wilbur Ellis and Harold Ernest opened Ellis and Ernest Drugstore near the University of Tennessee campus in 1926. For many years, E&E served as a popular gathering place for UT students as well as Knoxville residents and tourists. The drugstore was razed in the late 1960s in order to accommodate the Carolyn P. Brown University Center, but the establishment was commemorated with the Ellis and Ernest Friendship Walk.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knox County Court House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompsons Commercial Photographers
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greta Garbo in "Romance"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rotograph Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Candy Factory
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ayres Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Standard Souvenirs and Novelties, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ayres Hall, named for UT president Brown Ayres, was constructed in 1919 to replace decaying Old College, East College, and West College. Although money was raised to preserve Old College (dear to many alumni) it was discovered that its brick, which had been cheaply made, had decayed to the point that it was unsafe to move and the building was razed. Ayres Hall was dedicated in 1921 and has served as the campus's "landmark building" ever since. Chi Omega donated Ayres' first set of chimes in 1950, which rang every quarter hour until they were stolen by vandals in the early 1970s. The Class of 1991 replaced the chimes as their senior gift, thus reviving the tradition of "telling time by Ayres' chimes."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Will Geer and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion pictures, American
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Will Geer (who played Sheriff Hampton) and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Farragut
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Werner News Agency
Hotels -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Whittle Springs Hotel
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company/Publishers, Inc., 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA, 23510
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - SOCIAL LIFE AND CUSTOMS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville's First Market House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Row of "Shot Gun" houses on King Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hyde, Victor Albert, 1913-
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1939, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Knoxville, TN 37996
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Row of "Shot Gun" houses on Knoxville's King Street. According to Hyde, these homes are located in a D-Class neighborhood%3A one "occupied by negroes, irrespective of property value." Structures in these sections tend to be "of the poorest type, being constructed of unfinished lumber loosely thrown together and stripped" although some were previously part of slightly more prosperous C-Class neighborhoods.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John T. Whitaker and Mary Maverick (Lloyd) Whitaker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee. Dept. of Conservation
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: International organization
Foreign correspondents
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. The woman shown with Whitaker is most likely his first wife, Mary Maverick Lloyd (1905-1976), who devoted her life to the cause of world government and citizenship.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chilhowee Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chilhowee Lake (Tenn.)
Knox County (Tenn.) -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park#x0027;s lake. Visible are the extreme left side of the Liberal Arts Building (constructed for the National Conservation Exposition of 1913) and the lake#x0027;s distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lobby Card for "The Yearling"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Loew's Incorporated
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Yearling" tells the story of an American family living in Florida shortly after the Civil War. Ezra "Penny" Baxter (Gregory Peck) is a hardworking farmer struggling to support his wife, Orry (Jane Wyman), and single surviving son, Jody (Claude Jarman, Jr.). When Penny is bitten by a rattlesnake, he is forced to kill a doe to obtain the necessary antivenin. Jody begs to keep her orphaned faun, and his father agrees. When the faun becomes a yearling, however, it begins breaking into the garden that the family depends on for both food and money. As a result, Jody is forced to make a heartbreaking choice.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort James White
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
White, James, 1747-1821
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clay Brown Atkin (1864-1931) built the Hotel Atkin in the late 1870s on Knoxville's Gay Street. Atkin also ran a business manufacturing furniture and mantels, developed a number of other Knoxville and Fountain City properties, and served as director of a number of local organizations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: American Limestone Company Mine
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Mines and mineral resources -- Tennessee
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Industries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The American Limestone Company was established in 1913 to process some of the rock generated by the zinc mines near Knoxville. In 1971, the American Smelting and Refining Company (ASARCO) bought the American Limestone Company, including all four of its Knoxville mines. It continues to process limestone in East Tennessee today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Whitaker, John T. (John Thompson), 1906-
Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image most likely shows Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker (1898-1949), who was a prominent foreign correspondent for such newspapers as the New York Evening Post and the Philadelphia Public Ledger. He covered such conflicts as the Italo-Abyssinian War (1935-1936), the Spanish Civil War (1936-1937), and the Sino-Japanese War (1937) before working in Europe during World War II. He also taught journalism at Southern Methodist University (1922-1923) and wrote a number of books.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's Pavilion and Ayres Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Streets -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Intersection of Kingston Pike and Scenic Drive during the late 19th century. The Pike began as a 15-mile toll road stretching from Knoxville to Campbell's Station. It had been completely paved by the 1920s and began to develop as a commercial area in the 1930s. It still serves as a major Knoxville thoroughfare today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of Strong Hall (White Avenue Entrance)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: White Studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (tenn.) -- Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

According to Hyde, this area represents a C-type community: one occupied by caucasians where the total value of the property is $2500 or less. In 1939, the Knoxville Housing Authority was in the process of eliminating such areas as part of a slum clearance program.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- Untied States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dapprich, Frederic R, 1880-1965
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Los Angeles County (Calif.) -- Pictorial works
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

Airplane racing -- United States

At the National Air Races (held on July 1-4), Brown piloted the plane to 11,000 feet and Manning jumped to "thrill spectators in the grandstand." Manning, whose specialty was opening his parachute at the last moment, died in a boating accident later in the year.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist congregations: Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. Although membership has dwindled, the church continues to operate today.

Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Park City High School was built in 1907. For a brief time, it was the largest high school in Knoxville. It later became Park Lowry Grammar School and was closed in 1982. The building was sold to private contractors in the mid 1980s, but was completely razed after being badly damaged by fire in September of 1987.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Bridge and Tennessee River
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Whitaker and Unidentified Woman
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Foreign correspondents
Whitaker, John T. (John Thompson), 1906-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Donald Crisp in "National Velvet"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Crisp, Donald, 1880-1974
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clark Gable and Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
DICKINSON FAMILY
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Company Fatigue Detail
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawley, Thomas J, 1914-1999
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original caption for this image reads "Company fatigue detail - unloading gravel in company street. March-1941. Camp Barkley, Texas. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Woman's Building was originally constructed in 1897 as the Knoxville Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance to the World's Fair (Red Gate)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - DESCRIPTION AND TRAVEL - VIEWS
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cusine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Viaduct
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This bridge was built in 1876 in order to allow traffic on Gay Street to travel over the railroad tracks. It was replaced in 1919 when Gay Street's northern end was raised by 15 feet and a viaduct was constructed. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

Nov 14- 1940." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Rawls family
Hoskins family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "Deep Waters"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The film "Deep Waters," directed by Clarence Brown's mentor Maurice Tourneur, was adapted from the book "Caleb West: Master Diver" by Francis H. Smith and released in 1920. In the movie, Henry Sanford (Henry Woodward) is building a lighthouse at Keyport when he falls in love with Kate Leroy (Florence Deshon). Unfortunately, she is already married to wealthy Morgan Leroy (Jack McDonald). Simultaneously, Betty (Barbara Bedford), wife of master diver Caleb West (Broerkin Christians), attracts the attention of Bill Lacey (John Gilbert), who works with her husband. When Lacey is injured, Betty takes care of him and eventually agrees to run away with him. She soon repents of her rash action, but her husband will not take her back. Later, Lacey's ship is wrecked near the new lighthouse and West makes a dive to recover his body. Upon returning to the surface, he discovers that Betty has been operating his air pump, and the two reconcile.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Taylor, Elizabeth, 1932-
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.H. Kress & Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Tennessee River -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: E.C. Kropp Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
McClung Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Corporal Thomas J. Hawley Jr.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original caption for this image reads "Corp. Hawley. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div. Fort Sill Okla. Sept 1940-March 1941." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ewell Farm (Spring Hill, Tennessee)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Spring Hill (Tenn.) -- History
Maury County (Tenn.) -- Industry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Campbell Brown was born to Lizinka Campbell and James Percy Brown on November 27, 1840. He served in the Confederate Army during the Civil War and later operated his family's farm, called Ewell Farm, in Spring Hill (Maury County) Tennessee. Under his management, the farm expanded into one of the region's most prosperous plantations. After his death on July 30, 1893, his son Lucius Polk Brown took over the thriving family business.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Berry Funeral Home
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Promotion Service
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ralph Lawson Berry founded the Ralph L. Berry Funeral Home on September 20, 1928. His son, Fred O. Berry Sr., joined him in the business in 1934, but problems among the stockholders forced both to resign in 1936. In 1937, Ralph Berry, Fred Berry, and Edward Weigel founded the Berry Funeral Home on South Gay Street. In 1948, the business expanded when the Berry Funeral Home purchased and remodeled a structure (shown here) on Chapman Highway. A number of other major expansions were made in later years (including a merger with SCI Funeral Services of Tennessee) and Berry Funeral Home continues to operate as one of the most prestigious mortuary services in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - PUBLIC SCHOOLS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lookout Mountain (Appalachian Mountains)
Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park (Ga. and Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified man, Larkin Brown, and Clarence Brown sitting on "Umbrella Rock" in Point Park (located on Lookout Mountain near Chattanooga, Tennessee). A plaque near them commemorates the Battle of Wauhatchie. This battle, fought in southern Tennessee and northern Georgia on October 28-29, 1863, was one of the most significant night engagements of the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Detroit Publishing Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown and Helen Hayes on the Set of "Night Flight"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lionel Barrymore stars in "Night Flight" as Riviere, a dedicated pilot contracted to deliver mail. He is determined to keep to his schedule, even if it endangers his pilots. Among these airmen is Jules (Clark Gable) who does not respect Riviere but does his best to fulfill his expectations. After he is killed, Riviere has to tell his widow (Helen Hayes) that he is dead. Riviere does not, however, reduce his demands, even after he loses another pilot. Instead, he insists that more men be called up to ensure that the mail is delivered on time.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of John T. Whitaker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort James White
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.B. Newman Printing Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
White, James, 1747-1821
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Residences on Kingston Pike
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Werner News Agency
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles McClung built Kingston Pike in 1792. He also commissioned the first home to be built along the Pike, which he named "Statesview." Over the years, other wealthy Knoxvillians built more homes along the road, including Drury P. Armstrong's "Crescent Bend" (1832), Robert H. Armstrong's "Bleak House" (1856), and J.E. Lutz's "Westwood" (1890). Although the Pike has been heavily developed during the 20th century, some portions retain their original residential character.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: World's Fair Entrance (Red Gate) and Neyland Stadium
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

Soldiers -- South Dakota
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Snapshot of 1st Lieutenant Welby Matthew King and Staff Sergeant Lyle Howard Haug of the 109th Engineer Battalion taken during the unit's service in Africa. King (1919-1991) went on to serve in Korea and later settled in southern California. Haug (1918-2002) was a graduate of Madison Normal and taught elementary school in South Dakota before the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clarence Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight." The movie (based on the play of the same name by Robert Sherwood) stars Clark Gable as entertainer Harry Van. Van and his partner Madame Zuleika (Laura Hope Crews) have developed a "psychic" act in which Van gives the blindfolded Zuleika cues that allow her to accurately describe a member of the audience. Zuleika becomes so drunk, however, that she confuses her prompts (even when reminded loudly from offstage by Irene Fellara) and the couple are booed off stage. Years later, Van and Fellara (Norma Shearer) meet in a hotel in Geneva and a series of antics ensue. The pair's shallow lives provide a vivid counterpoint to a world on the brink of war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins and Betsey Olivia Beeler
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Creekmore, Betsey Beeler, 1915-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Bessie Hoskins married Ulysses Beeler in 1897, and the couple had one child, Betsey, in 1915. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: World's Fair Grounds (showing the Technology and Lifestyle Center and the International Court of Flags)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Blount Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: BLOUNT, WILLIAM, - 1749-1800
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Market House and Market Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Published 1978, The Donning Company, 253 West Bute Street, Norfolk, VA 23510
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Me-Na-Wa, a Creek Warrior
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: King, Charles Bird, 1785-1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: E.C. Biddle
Published 1868
Rice, Rutter, and Company, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
Creek Indians -- Kings and rulers.
Creek Indians -- Tribal government.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Menawa (meaning The Great Warrior) was chief of the Oakfuskee Creek towns lying on the Tallapoosa River in Alabama. He was widely known as a talented and brutal warrior. A determined opponent of both Creek Chief William MacIntosh and MacIntosh's 1825 Treaty of Indian Springs (which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government), Menawa took part in the 1826 delegation to Washington, DC designed to repudiate the treaty. Although the group failed to have the treaty revoked, Menawa was instrumental in having a provision inserted allowing the Creek to obtain legal patents for their land. He, along with Opothle Yoholo, later fought alongside American troops against the Seminole in Alabama. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826, when Menawa was said to be about sixty years old. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Monroe Howard
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Brownlow, William Gannaway, 1805-1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brian, David, 1914-1993
Motion pictures, American
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John T. Whitaker with Unidentified Group
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Foreign correspondents
World War, 1939-1945 -- Journalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. This photograph may have been taken during one of Whitaker's lecture tours.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Brown Directing "The Eagle"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Silent films -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. James Hotel
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. The building served as married and graduate student housing until 2006, when New York developer Stanley Mohr bought the property with plans to turn it into a private apartment building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Camp Barkley Field Kitchen
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawley, Thomas J, 1914-1999
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th
World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original caption for this image reads "Our Kitchen in which we ate from just before our Battle with the 157th Inf. March-31-1941. Camp Barkley Texas. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Intruder in the Dust" Cast Members and Unidentified Others
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion pictures, American
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Intruder in the Dust" cast members and unidentified others (possibly local dignitaries who visited while "Intruder" was shooting on location in Nashville, Tennessee). The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Se-Loc-Ta, a Creek Chief
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: King, Charles Bird, 1785-1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Frederick W. Greenough
Published 1868
Rice, Rutter and Company, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
Creek Indians -- Kings and rulers.
Creek Indians -- Wars.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Selocta was the son of principal Creek chief Chinnaby, who supported the United States during the Creek War of 1813-1814. Selocta served as a guide and warrior during the conflict, and was eventually instrumental in negotiating the peace settlement. It was in part due to his influence that the Creek later ceded their land on the Alabama River. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance to the World's Fair (Showing Neyland Stadium)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence and Marion Brown
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Marion Ruth Spies was born in Ohio on January 22, 1905. She worked as a schoolteacher before moving to Hollywood in search of a more exciting life. She married director Clarence L. Brown on November 10, 1947. He had previously been married to Paul (called Polly) Pratt, Ona Maris, and Alice Joyce. Later in life, Marion Brown became one of the major forces behind the Browns' many contributions to the University of Tennessee. Clarence Brown died on August 17, 1987 and Marion Brown followed on May 10, 1993.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Pickle Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knox County Court House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Standard News Agency
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Visible in the background is the Hotel Andrew Johnson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brown on the Set of "Sadie McKee"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sadie McKee (Joan Crawford) is a cook's daughter and works a maid for the wealthy Alderson family. Although she flirts with her employer, Mike Alderson (Franchot Tone), she loves her humble boyfriend Tommy Wallace (Gene Raymond). The couple runs away to New York to get married, but before the ceremony Wallace meets a showgirl and deserts McKee. She decides to stay in the city, and gets a job in a nightclub owned by alcoholic millionaire Jack Brennan (Edward Arnold). Brennan is smitten with McKee, who eventually gives up on finding true love and marries Brennan for his money. She is unhappy, however, and leaves him when she finds out that Wallace is in trouble. With Alderson's help, she eventually discovers that he is extremely ill in a hospital. She goes to visit him, and he pair confess their love for each other shortly before Wallace dies.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Possessed"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crowds at the World's Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Fairs
World's Fair of 1982 (Knoxville, Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
Exhibitions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. James Hotel
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Farragut
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tennessee -- Pictorial works.
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Students in Strong Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Cora de Garmo Bryan
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schweig Studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nutritionists -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo (1891-1986) taken at her wedding to Charles W. Bryan (1890-1966) on May 9, 1920. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville Engraving Co.
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oakwood Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
McClung Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Machinery and Liberal Arts Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chilhowee Lake (Tenn.)
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Machinery and Liberal Arts Building was constructed in Chilhowee Park as part of the 1913 National Conservation Exposition. Although this event dealt only with local issues, it was an ambitious attempt to educate citizens and businessmen about the importance of conserving natural resources. The Exposition was sponsored by President Theodore Roosevelt and continued previous efforts in the field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Appalachian Avenue on the Appalachian Exposition Grounds
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chapman Drug Co.
Expositions -- Tennessee -- Knoxville
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawing Room in the Blount Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: William Blount Mansion Association
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Blount, William, 1749-1800
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. The portraits on the far wall show William Blount (left) and his half-brother Willie Blount.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Gillette Ranch
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson's, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, Structures, Etc. -- Pictorial Works
Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greta Garbo in "Romance"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Clarence, 1890-1987
Motion picture producers and directors -- United States
Motion pictures -- United States
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Southern Railway Depot
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: S.H. Kress & Co.
Southern Railway (U.S.)
Railroads -- Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knox County Court House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Knoxville (Tenn.) -- History.
KNOXVILLE (TENN.) - BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC. - PICTORIAL WORKS
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Distinguished group of intercollegiate agriculturalists
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
University of Tennessee, Knoxville  Pictorial works
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Distinguished group of agriculturalists who sailed on United Fruit lines SS San Jose from New Orleans, July 31, on an agricultural inspection trip to Honduras and Guatemala. They are guests of the United Fruit Company. It is expected that their reactions will prove beneficial to relationships between the Americas and the improvement of agricultural conditions. Front Row (L-R) C.E. Brehm, University of Tennessee, H.P. Cooper, Clemson Agricultural College, R.S. Hawkins, University of Arizon
